As I understand it the pope can not retire, it is a position for life.

Alan Ryan

I haven't researched this in detail, but I believe the history of the papacy includes several popes who have resigned or been deposed. At one time two popes simultaneously claimed jurisdiction over the Catholic church (one in Rome, the other at Avignon). One of them had to take "early retirement".
 I don't think the present pope will retire: he has said that his suffering is the will of God and that he will persevere to the end.

 All enter into death. But, PJP will live forever in the presence of the one he worshipped. He has learned much through his suffering. No one would think it cruel that a parent allows a child to take a risk and get hurt so as to learn. Provided the child doesn't perish. The pope has not perished. He lives forever. 
 
 I see no cruelty in that at all. You see, if you believe that your life can never be taken from you as the pope did, then you can live completely for God with great abandon and have your life count for much, as his did. His life is not lost. Here on earth it had only just begun.
